ORDER

Petitioner is the accused in Crime No.731/2022 of Kannur Police
Station, Kannur alleging offences under various provisions of the
Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Stances Act, 1985. By Annexure Al
order in B.A.No.5207/2022, this Court while granting bail to the
petitioner in the aforementioned crime directed that he shall not involve
in any other crime while on bail. In the meanwhile, petitioner is alleged
to have involved in a serious offence, and is arrayed as 2™ accused in
Crime No.236/2023 of Valapttanam Police Station for the offences under
Sections 392, 323, 364A and 365 r/w Section 34 of the Indian Penal
Code, 1860.

2. In the latter case, which was allegedly committed while the
petitioner was on bail, the prosecution alleged that the accused came in
a motor car and after abducting the defacto complainant and his friends
robbed their mobile phone and demanded ransom for its release.
Immediately after commission of the second offence the Investigating

Officer in Crime No.731/2022 filed Crl.M.P. No.537/2022 seeking
cancellation of bail granted to the accused for violation of the conditions.
By a detailed order dated 13.10.2023 produced as Annexure A Ill the
learned Sessions Judge cancelled the bail after noticing that the
allegations do not indicate any false implication and also that the nature
of offence alleged against the accused includes abduction, robbery and
demand of ransom, all of which are serious offences.

3. Sri.Aswanth.P.T., learned Counsel for the petitioner
contended that the impugned order is not legally tenable, since the
court had not considered various parameters for cancelling the bail. It is
also submitted that the learned Sessions Judge while cancelling the bail
failed to bear in mind the settled legal preposition that unless the liberty
granted to the accused would prejudice the conduct of trial, bail ought
not to be cancelled. The learned Counsel referring to the decision in
Godson vs. State of Kerala 2022 ICO 1505 contended that the mere
implication of the accused in the subsequent offence by itself ought not
to be a ground for cancellation of bail.

4. Sri.K.A.Noushad, learned Public Prosecutor on the other hand
contended that petitioner committed a serious offence, which has a
tendency to interfere with the trial. as the accused had abducted the
defacto complainant and demanded ramson, which can indirectly create
fear and terror in the mind of the witnesses in the earlier case and
thereby prejudice the trial and, if on that basis the bail is not cancelled

2024/KER/7383
CRL.MC NO. 97 OF 2024
4
the witnesses in the NDPS case may not come forward to give evidence.

5. Petitioner, though a young person of 24 years, is alleged to
have involved in NDPS offence in Crime No.731/2022 of Kannur Town
Police Station. He was released on bail by order dated 10.08.2022.
Within five months thereafter, he is alleged to have involved himself in
Crime No.226/2023 of Valapattanam Police Station by committing a
serious offence of abduction and demand of ransom.

6. As rightly pointed out by the learned Public Prosecutor, the
condition imposed in Annexure AI bail order is that, he shall not involve
in any other crime while on bail. Despite such conditions having been
imposed by this Court, petitioner involved in a crime of a serious nature
like abduction and demand of ransom, certainly, it can spell out terror
and fear in the mind of the witnesses, who are to be examined in Crime
No.731/2022 of Kannur Town police Station. If in total disregard of the
conditions, petitioner has committed the offence and if the bail is not
cancelled, the trial in the said crime can be prejudiced. Therefore, the
contention raised by the learned Counsel for the petitioner relying upon
Godson’s case (supra) is not legally tenable.

7. On a perusal of the impugned order and on considering the
decision in P vs. State of M.P. [2022 (7) SCALE 411], it is noticed
that the learned Sessions Judge has mentioned detailed reasons for
cancelling the bail granted to the petitioner. It has also been specifically
observed that there is no reason to assume that petitioner has been
